variant.question: An N~1~ gauge reads:
In the picture, which conical AoA probe is moving in the direction indicated.
The null-seeking probe uses (1) for measurement and is subjected to (2) error.
Which of the following systems can make use of Air Data Computer output data?

Refer to figure.  
  The null-seeking (slotted) probe AOA sensor of (1) __ will automatically rotate (2) __ to automatically seek a balance point.

During a flight in icing conditions the AoA sensor vanes become frozen and stuck in their current position. The crew are NOT aware of this and the Pilot Flying lowers the nose of the aeroplane to start a descent. What will be the AoA reading?

options.text: The same AoA as during level flight, thus providing false data.
No AoA indication in combination with a warning of a fault in these sensors.
The correct AoA for the descent, as other systems will compensate for the stuck AoA sensors.
The force of the airflow when starting the descent will crack the ice, the AoA vanes will operate again and provide the correct AoA.

variant.question: If the static ports are completely clogged up by ice during a climb, the vertical speed indicator shows:

options.text: a descent if the ambient static pressure is less than the pressure in the instrument.
a constant rate of climb, even if the aircraft is levelling out.
an increasing rate of climb if the ambient static pressure decreases.

variant.question: How are vane type angle of attack sensors are protected against icing?

options.text: By using thermal electric anti icing.
By using thermal pneumatic anti icing.

variant.question:
Complete the following phrase:
The signal on an angle of attack sensor is created by a (1)__ and is subject to (2)__ error.

An angle of attack sensor may consist of: - an inertial system computing the difference between flight path and flight attitude. - a conical slotted probe which positions itself to determine the angle of attack. - a vane detector which positions the rotor of a synchro-transmitter. The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:
On aeroplanes with Flight-envelope protection, an incorrect, lower-than-actual AoA measurement may...

options.text: Lead to inadequate protection when approaching the critical AoA
Cause earlier-than-normal pitch auto trim stopping
Prevent extension of the leading edge and trailling edge devices for landing
Prevent the aircraft from entering in to an uncontrollable state

variant.question: What system uses an output of the Air Data Computer?
On aeroplanes with Flight-envelope protection system, an under-read of the actual AoA measurement may...

options.text: lead to inadequate protection when approaching the critical AoA.
prevent extension of the leading edge and trailing edge devices for landing.
prevent the aircraft from entering into an uncontrollable state.
cause earlier-than-normal pitch auto trim stopping.

variant.question: How is the angle of attack sensor protected from icing?

options.text: it isn't, no protection is required

If the pitot tubes ice up during flight, the affected indication(s) is (are):
1. altitude
2. vertical speed
3. airspeed

Which of the following is not an input to a full stall warning system?
If the static source to an altimeter becomes blocked during a climb, the instrument will

options.text: continue to indicate the reading at which the blockage occurred.
under-read by an amount equivalent to the reading at the time that the instrument became blocked.

NB: the original Quadrant type question had two drop downs and four choices in each
Which one of the following systems can make use of Air Data Computer output data?
The AoA vane feeds its output to...
Diagram 4 in the annex represents:

options.text: a left turn with insufficient rudder.
a right turn with insufficient rudder.
a left turn with too much rudder.

variant.question: Diagram 4 in the annex is showing:

options.text: a 40° left bank and 15° nose up attitude.
a 20° left bank and 18° nose down attitude.
a 40° right bank and 8° nose down attitude.
a 40° left bank and 15° nose down attitude.

variant.question: If the static pressure port iced over while descending from altitude, the airspeed indicator would read

The main inputs to the flight envelope protection system are:
1. GPWS signals
2. ACAS signals
3. angle of attack
4. bank angle
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:

The flight envelope protection function(s) consist(s) of: - Alerting the flight crew in case of dangerous proximity with the ground - Avoiding midair collision - Preventing the aircraft from exceeding some aerodynamic limits The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:

The flight envelope protection function(s) consist(s) of
1) automatically performing an evasion manoeuvre if necessary.
2) preventing the aircraft from exceeding the limits for specific flight parameters.
3) alerting the flight crew in case of dangerous proximity with a threatening traffic.
4) preventing any incursion beyond an ATC clearance.The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is

The flight envelope protection system prevents the aircraft from exceeding the limits of the following parameters (among others):
1. cabin altitude
2. bank angle
3. angle of attack
4. speed
5. pitch angle
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:

Which of the following is an example of a flight envelope protection system that generates warning signals to indicate when a limit is being approached (referred to as a soft flight envelope protection system)?
State an example of a flight envelope protection system (soft flight envelope protection system), which gives warning signal as soon as a limit will be approached:
A flight envelope protection system is a system

options.text: that generates a control signal when the aircraft exceeds the flight envelope limit.
that generates a signal during flight when engine parameters only are exceeded.
required to generate an ACAS warning.
that generates a signal when the engines have exceeded the start envelope limit.

variant.question: What can be expected when there's a complete loss of GPS signal?

options.text: Loss of integrity monitoring (RAIM) and RNP APCH capability.
Position uncertainty due to ND units shutdown.

variant.question:
The stall warning system of a large transport airplane includes:
1) an angle of attack sensor.
2) a computer.
3) a transmitter originating from the anemometer.
4) an independent pitot probe.
5) a transmitter of the flap/slat position indicating system.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
The angle of attack is used as an input to which of the following systems to get a wind-shear warning?
Which of these signals are inputs, at least, in the stall warning computers?

options.text: Angle of attack and flaps and slats deflection.
Angle of attack, flaps deflection and EPR.
Angle of attack and flaps and spoilers deflection.
Angle of attack, flaps deflection, EPR and N1.

variant.question: The system which takes an input of angle of attack from the ADC to give windshear alerts is:
Which of the following systems uses the angle of attack input to detect wind shear?

A large commercial aeroplane is performing a test flight. It maintains level flight and reduces speed towards the indicated stick-shaker speed. If all Angle of Attack (AOA) sensors become frozen at an angle corresponding to level flight, stall warning and protection systems will...

options.text: not trigger at all or not function as expected.
function properly because the AoA information will be disregarded.
not be affected because their source is pitch and speed information.
function properly by alternate inputs from the Air Data Computer.

variant.question: A large commercial aeroplane is performing a test flight. It maintains level flight and reduced speed towards the indicated stick-shaker speed. If all angle of Attack (AOA) sensors become frozen at an angle corresponding to level flight, stall warning and protection system will...

options.text: NOT trigger at all or NOT function as expected.
function properly because the AoA information will be disregarded.
NOT be affected because their source is pitch and speed information.
function properly by alternate inputs from the Air Data Computer.

variant.question: Refer to the image. The ‘O’ followed by the letters ‘KABC’ indicates...
The white arrow in the lower-left corner indicates

options.text: current wind of 305°/8 kts is being experienced.
after passing XYZ waypoint in 8 minutes the next heading will be 305°.
active waypoint (XYZ) is located on radial 305° and 8 NM from a VOR tuned in the active NAV receiver.
active waypoint (T/D) is located on radial 305° and 8 NM from a VOR tuned in the active NAV receiver.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 062-10.
The "O" followed by the letters "KABC" indicates in figure 3:
What are the control surface position sensors used for?

options.text: Comparing the directed inputs with the actual surface movement.
To inhibit the control surface exceeding their aerodynamic limitations.
Detecting a restricted movement/jamming in a control surface.
Comparing the restricted inputs with the actual surface movement.
